docs.snippet: In exploring the notion of personal legacy, the longing to bequeath something lasting after death, Ventura Pons's impassioned movie ''Amic/Amat'' (''Friend'') goes where no film has gone before. This prickly psycho-sexual bramble bush of a movie, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In exploring the notion of personal legacy, the longing to bequeath something lasting after death, Ventura Pons's impassioned movie ''Amic/Amat'' (''Friend'') goes where no film has gone before. This prickly psycho-sexual bramble bush of a movie, which opens the 16-film series ''Instituto Cervantes Spanish Cinema Now'' at the Walter Reade Theater today, focuses on a portly middle-aged gay professor of medieval literature who is dying of an unidentified illness and putting his life in order before carrying out an assisted suicide. On discovering that his most brilliant student, a smoldering nihilistic rebel (whose father also killed himself) has impregnated the daughter of his best friend, the professor hatches a plan to make the child his heir. For decades, the professor was unrequitedly in love with the girl's father, who is now his trusted university colleague. At the same time, the professor is masochistically infatuated with his favorite student, whom he discovers is moonlighting as a male hustler.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden Critic's Choice review of movie Amic/Amat (Friend), which opens Instituto Cervantes Spanish Cinema Now event at Walter Reade Theater; film is first of six in series by Catalan director Ventura Pons(S)

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Spanish consular official in San Francisco recently told Japanese camp sopkesmen at Tule Lake and Menzanar that American citizens of Japanese ancestry who were confined in the camps were not subject to induction in the arm...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Spanish consular official in San Francisco recently told Japanese camp sopkesmen at Tule Lake and Menzanar that American citizens of Japanese ancestry who were confined in the camps were not subject to induction in the armed forces of the United States.
docs.abstract: Spanish Embassy corrects draft advice to Japanese in relocation camps

headline.main: SPANISH AIDE'S ADVICE ON DRAFT CORRECTED; Embassy Acts on Word Given to Citizens of Japanese Origin

docs.snippet: Ennio Falco of Italy, nearly perfect through two days of shooting, won the gold medal in skeet. Falco's score of 149 at the Wolf Creek Shooting Complex in Atlanta was one target short of the world record of 150 shared by his countryman, the bronze...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ennio Falco of Italy, nearly perfect through two days of shooting, won the gold medal in skeet. Falco's score of 149 at the Wolf Creek Shooting Complex in Atlanta was one target short of the world record of 150 shared by his countryman, the bronze medalist Andrea Benelli, and Jan Henrik Heinrich of Germany. Miroslaw Rzepkowski of Poland won the silver with a score of 148. In the 50-meter free rifle three-position event, the four-time Olympian Jean-Pierre Amat of France beat out Sergey Beliaev of Kazakstan for the gold medal. Wolfram Waibel Jr. of Austria took the bronze. (AP)
